I have changed my mind. It's a painful and slow process for all the reasons explained in the video. I'll add, if we're all trying to figure out how to change someone else's opinion because they're so clearly wrong, we might all be missing the point. Be ever willing to re-evaluate your position based on new information. Approach each discussion with humility. The more I've learned, the less I know. And because I spend every working day surrounded by people I disagree with, I spend far more time listening and asking questions than I spend debating and offering my own opinions. Ultimately, politicized issues do tend to divide. The topics should be discussed, but most people aren't ready or mature enough to do it in a productive manner (myself included). Maybe instead we need to focus on seeing "the other" as part of our "in group" by uniting around shared values and goals.

comment_text: Beliver vs Deniers

How Can You Change Somebody's Opinion". That of course depends on the psychology of the individual or group of individuals concerned. For example it can be very difficult (though not impossible) to help people reevaluate their deeply held opinions ....erm? whoops, deeply held beliefs. And quite often those in opposition to any particular beliefs use sound byte words which they themselves don't comprehend on a practical level. A typical argument would be "your delusional" or "stupid" for believing that nonsense.
Whilst it's a fact that understanding can lead to a more accurate perception of reality, there is no such thing as a non-delusional human (of course there is a large variance in human delusion). Delusions and illusions are evolution's answer (consciousness tool box) that enable a conscious animal to navigate the environment it exists within ( A reality that no human has the perception to 100% comprehend , 100% of the time (humans are not deities. the god delusion being one major component of huge misunderstandings of reality).

A narrative to focus the point:

Many very young western children are encouraged by there peers (parents, relatives etc) to believe in father Christmas. These children ,on average, are more happy at that particular time of year than those whom don't believe in father Christmas due to the "magic" they imagine in their own subjective minds (though it could be argued that the happiness is predominantly because children, like there peers, like getting lots of new stuff at Christmas time) . Thus it could be suggested that the father Christmas delusion/belief is a healthy belief when compared to a more sinister form of belief.
Of course all these children eventually lose their faith in father Christmas, some completely and some transition towards a more "mature" belief like Christianity with sadly it's more "sinister" (and unhealthier) psychology undercurrents preached by some believers. e.g. Hell and original Sin.

The point being is that delusion in it's self is neither good or bad ( healthy or pathological). It's the behavior that delusions can encourage/motivate that maybe beneficial/or not, to the organism (inc human) , the population of organisms or the genes (quite often the behavior is for the benefit of the genes). There are some minds that need changing (or restricting from imposing there ill actions on society) as they pose a real threat to humanity. However, there are many delusional minds that are not threats ( well at least not threatening on a inter-species/inter-human population scale, not so much on a ecological scale, as we are going to realise, I hope!, sooner rather than the worse scenarios that will come later if we don't ) , in fact there happy delusions can be beneficial to a culture depending on the cultural context (e.g. delusions are what the scientific method mitigates to some degree or another in order to focus on inquiring more robust facts. Delusions ( day dreaming etc) can be dangerous whilst driving/handling machinery thus a more objective concentration on the practical task at hand is needed).

My favorite delusion of all is conscious awareness >>> ( "It" of course exists unless your a tree or a rock. Though plants react biologically to there environment which is why consciousness evolved in the first instance (cite lots of biological research here ) >>> That for many producers a delusion that conscious minds are what it takes to make something that in retrospect looks like (on the surface) has been designed by a " intelligent creator" (intelligent design). Billions fall for this delusion and will continue to do so unless they study the process of evolution at a level in which they comprehend Algorithms. Of course if a individual has no decent concept of evolution (which all the empirical evidenced points >>>> towards being a robust scientific theory (like cell theory. And many have tried to find scientific ways to disprove evolution) then they will merely think " human creates stuff, therefore something created human, therefore god made humans". The anthropocentric way of comprehending reality (human first inc human belief systems) has been shown time and time again to be incorrect.e.g. The Earth isn't in the centre of the solar system and a deity isn't in the center (or anywhere else) of our existence ( unless? anybody have a comprehensible unless?). And as the gaps in our scientific knowledge become increasingly smaller it will actually do humans a hell of a lot of good to drop the competitive driven ego's ( at least where cooperation is the winning strategy).

The distance future for humans is unforeseeable. Though it's predictable and science can (has already on average) make "it" a more safer enjoyable place to be. Slightly ignoring the terrible offshoots of science like the Atom bomb. BUT, give a axe ( a tool like science) to a wise person and this person will leave the tree standing, unless it's harvested in a sustainable method, give a axe to a psychologically unstable person or nation or group of nations and .......?. substitute the axe for the energy discovered by splitting the atom. Ok, I'll quit now before I go off any various tangents, one of which would of been a narrative about how an effective way to comprehend something is to break it than try to fix it. Though, this method won''t work with the planets ecosystem for pretty obvious reasons. So don't "fix" that which wasn't broken before humans started to seriously "modify" it ( break it in tiny steps over time due to a lack of the big picture and a comprehensive ecosystem health plan.e.g. The study of ecology etc)

Not even a plumber, but a toilet works by keeping the water in the bowl at a certain level. There's a sideways S-shaped tube in the toilet that connects from the bowl to some pipes leading to your septic tank. The reason it's S-shaped is so that water doesn't flow down into the pipes, keeping it at a certain leve where the water sits just below the curve of the S. When you flush the toilet, you bring in a large amount of new, usually clean, water from the water tank. The new water causes the total water level to rise, which means the water can now go past the sideways S-shaped tube. Basically, the new water forces the old water past the S-shape. As for zippers, they're simple. Every single tooth on a zipper is basically a hook. Each hook stacks up on top of the other tooth on the other side of the zipper, but only when they enter each other at a specific angle. That's what the zip thing is for. It basically guides the teeth to stack on top of each other at their specific angle, and unstacks them at another specific angle. And computers, or pretty much any piece of technology, I've never claimed to understand how they work, they're too complicated. Suck on that, AsapSCIENCE.

To attempt to change someone is manipulative. To attempt to change someone else's mind corrupts the honesty of one's own message. The only good way to communicate is to be honest, perhaps purposeful, and let the results be as they are; if there is any change made to the message in order to try to control the outcome then truthfulness will not flow freely and the message will drastically suffer in both effectiveness and accuracy. Also, opinions are not even worth interfering with. Anything that is the assessment and/or recognition of reality is a matter of fact, not opinion. In the case of facts some people are correct and some are incorrect. Being wrong about a fact does not make it an opinion, and having limited knowledge with which to assess information also does not make a matter of fact a matter of opinion. In fact, due to the depth of reason, opinion is extremely rare, maybe nonexistent; most everything has objective truth, usually expressed tautologically through accuracy of vocabulary, and is therefor a matter of fact.

Toilet: a device usually made out of porcelain constructed of a flush box, flush box cover, bowl and seat which is set on a drain pipe with a flange. A toilet works by pumping water into a reservoir, releasing it over the excrement to push it over a waterlock. I'm not a plumber, I'm just curious about things.

A zipper works by pushing rods with grooves and bumps at an angle to fit within each other. Could explain better with pen and paper, but I do understand the mechanics. I'm just curious, so I have actually looked at how it works. There are more details I could tell you, but it's just so much easier to explain it with a diagram.

A computer is a much more complex thing, but in VERY general terms, a processor can take input that comes as a series of current and no current and through using semi conductors, you're able to do logical operations on that information. This means you're able to add and subtract things, true and false operators etc. If anyone were to actually read this, I could go on with how you find memory and layers of abstractions of computer languages and how representation of colors, letters, numbers, internet communication work through convention. But that would take more time than I'm willing to spend now. I don't know any details, because knowing details require more studies than I have done.

I have already gone through the experience of having baseless opinions though, I had a few friends who were politically active and I liked discussing things, so I joined, but I quickly got indoctrinated in certain opinions, with filters, but not enough. Once I realized this, I quit the group and decided that I needed to learn more about these things before having an opinion. The problems we discussed and were supposed to have an opinion on, were really too complex without years and years of experience and study.

When confronted with a person that has a different opinion than you, simply ask the person to explain why they believe what they believe. You know, actually listening to people before jumping to the conclusion that you know all of it and are absolutely right in the thing you're discussing. Believing that you can be wrong and wanting to know more about what the person you're talking to thinks, is the way to avoid becoming the ignorant one. And unless you understand where their reasoning is wrong, how can you get them to understand? Are you really just going to repeat the generic propaganda that you usually come up with from your group think? I expect that I still have false beliefs, and try to watch out for opportunities to learn more from others that I talk about? I put questions in their minds. I spent about an hour each with a few mormons that approached me about god. I then managed to have them question their beliefs. I've given people who dislike capitalism an understanding of what it is, and made them question if it's such a bad thing. How? I asked them and waited for them to ask me.

When I was younger, I asked my teacher about global warming. He wasn't able to answer me, because he didn't understand it. Yet he said he did and basically hinted at the fact that you're a bad person if you don't. Thus I concluded, he is stupid and I won't listen to him. Until a few years later, I didn't believe in the CO2 global warming theory, because all I heard was explanations from people who didn't understand it. Whenever I would question it, I would be labeled as a science denier. But hey, I didn't understand it, and questioning it is how you learn, right? So for those years, I thought it was just political, because that's how it seemed. Scientists aren't immune to politics, especially if there is financial support behind one outcome. Now, I am unsure about it, and that's fine for me, until I take some time to understand it. In this case, I leave it to those that study it in depth. I no longer question anyone to learn, and I've been put off from learning about it. It's probably one of those things I have a bias towards.
But the reason why my beliefs were muddled, was because of all the people spreading the gospel of global warming without knowing shit. Please don't be that person.

Yeah, I figured this out a while back. The emotional argument is how to convince emotional people. You have to directly find a way to better their own life (and your own?). Too many people talk about things, which people can not link to their own day to day life and their own problems (in the short term).If they can't link to their own life, they'll assume negatively about yours - because they'll assume you're profiting without telling them how (they'll believe you are being greedy concealing information). Politics seemed too disconnected. Only now with Trump & Theresa May, people are starting to actually think far more, as the level of political conversation has matched/clashes with what they were already thinking. We can also expose them to the dangers of their own ideology/weak solutions via linking to real world examples (videos) of other places in the world which aren't so dandy. An example being New Delhi, where air pollution has gotten so bad on the roads, that it's like smoking 43 cigarettes a day (Example of how privatisation has failed: https://twitter.com/BBCWorld/status/928257210488180736 ). Even without mentioning the trigger word 'climate change' - it still gets people to worry about the problems of air pollution and how to go about solving it. This in affect helps deal with climate change - just getting them to accept this fact (video evidence) will stir their mind and is more likely to convince. Take them on a holiday to there if you must - to make them see the reality with their own two eyes (becomes a part of their reality once they physically see it).
